pgTitle: List of American Civil War Medal of Honor recipients: A–F

rows.text: Error: 1863 Nov 20 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.

Conducted the "burning party" of his regiment at the time a charge was made on the enemy's picket line, and burned the house which had sheltered the enemy's sharpshooters, thus insuring success to a hazardous enterprise.
Error: 1864 May 12 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Was one of the first to mount the Confederate works, where he bayoneted two of the enemy and captured a Confederate flag, but threw it away to continue the pursuit of the enemy.

Error: 1862 May This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input. and Error: 1864 Jun This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Error: 1863 Jul 3 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Error: 1865 Apr 2 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Capture of silk Confederate States flag and 2 staff officers.
Error: 1863 December 25 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.

Served on board the U.S.S. Marblehead off Legareville, Stono River, 25 December 1863, during an engagement with the enemy on John's Island. Behaving in a gallant manner, Farley animated his men and kept up a rapid and effective fire on the enemy throughout the engagement which resulted in the enemy's abandonment of his positions, leaving a caisson and 1 gun behind
Error: 1864 Jun 11 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Voluntarily carried a message which stopped the firing of a Union battery into his regiment, in which service he crossed a ridge in plain view and swept by the fire of both armies.
Error: 1862 Dec 31 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.

When a break occurred on the extreme right wing of the Army of the Cumberland, this soldier rallied fugitives from other commands, and deployed his own regiment, thereby checking the Confederate advance until a new line was established.
Error: 1862 April 24 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Served on board the U.S.S. Owasco during the attack upon Forts Jackson and St. Philip, 24 April 1862.
Error: 1864 May 12 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Capture of flag of 2nd Louisiana Tigers (C.S.A.) in a hand-to-hand contest.
Error: 1863 Jul 2 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
While acting as an aide, voluntarily led a regiment to the relief of a battery and recaptured its guns from the enemy.
Error: 1865 Apr 1 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
During a rush at the enemy, Lt. Fernald seized, during a scuffle, the flag of the 9th Virginia Infantry (C.S.A.).
Error: 1864 December 6 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Served on board the U.S. Monitor Neosho during the engagement with enemy batteries at Bells Mills, Cumberland River, near Nashville, Tenn., 6 December 1864.
Error: 1864 May 9 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.

While his regiment was retreating, voluntarily gave up his horse to his brigade commander who had been unhorsed and was in danger of capture, thereby enabling him to rejoin and rally the disorganized troops. Sgt. Ferrier himself was captured and confined in Confederate prisons, from which he escaped and, after great hardship, rejoined the Union lines.
Error: 1865 Apr 1 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.

Accompanied only by an orderly, outside the lines of the Army, he gallantly resisted an attack of 5 of Mosby's cavalry, mortally wounded the leader of the party, seized his horse and pistols, wounded 3 more, and, though wounded himself, escaped.
Error: 1865 Apr 2 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Capture of flag of 18th North Carolina (C.S.A.) within the enemy's works.
Error: 1865 April 9 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
While on the advance skirmish line and within direct and close fire of the enemy's artillery, crossed the mill race on a burning bridge and ascertained the enemy's position.
Error: 1863 May 22 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Gallantry in the charge of the "volunteer storming party."
Error: 1865 Apr 2 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Carried the colors 50 yards in advance of his regiment, and after being painfully wounded attempted to crawl into the enemy's works in an endeavor to plant his flag thereon.
Error: 1864 August 5 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
As captain of the No. 1 gun on board the flagship U.S.S. Hartford, during action against rebel gunboats, the ram Tennessee and Fort Morgan in Mobile Bay, 5 August 1864.
Error: 1864 Sep 29 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Gallantry in the charge on the enemy's works: rushing forward with the colors and calling upon the men to follow him; was severely wounded.
Error: 1863 Feb 15 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Was one of a detachment of 16 men who heroically defended a wagon train against the attack of 125 cavalry, repulsed the attack and saved the train.
Error: 1864 Sep 29 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Seized the regimental colors and led the regiment after 2 color bearers had been shot down.

Error: 1862 April 24 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input. and Error: 1862 April 25 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Served on board the U.S.S. Pensacola in the attack on Forts Jackson and St. Philip and at the taking of new Orleans, 24 and 25 April 1862.
Error: 1863 Jul 3 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Capture of flag of 52d North Carolina Infantry (C.S.A.).
Error: 1863 May 22 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Gallantry in the charge of the "volunteer storming party."

Error: 1862 Mar 3 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input. and Error: 1862 Dec 31 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.

At New Madrid, Mo., remained on duty though severely wounded. While procuring ammunition from the supply train at Stone River, Tenn., was captured, but made his escape, secured the ammunition, and in less than an hour from the time of his capture had the batteries supplied.
Error: 1864 Jul 22 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Charged upon the enemy's works, and after their capture defended his position against assaults of the enemy until he was severely wounded.
Error: 1865 Apr 6 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Error: 1862 May 31 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Although wounded, he continued fighting until, fainting from loss of blood, he was carried off the field.
Error: 1862 Sep 15 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Voluntarily gathered the men of the battery together, remanned the guns, which had been ordered abandoned by an officer, opened fire, and kept up the same on the enemy until after the surrender.
Error: 1862 Dec 23 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.

When his command was surrounded by a greatly superior force, voluntarily left the shelter of the breastworks, crossed an open railway trestle under a concentrated fire from the enemy, made his way out and secured reinforcements for the relief of his command.
Error: 1864 Sep 19 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Error: 1863 Jun 14 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Made 2 trips across an open space, in the face of the enemy's concentrated fire, and secured water for the sick and wounded.
Error: 1865 Apr 2 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Bravely assisted in the capture of one of the enemy's guns; with the first troops to enter the city, captured the flag of the Confederate customhouse.

Error: 1865 January 13 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input. – Error: 1865 January 15 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Served on board the U.S.S. Rhode Island during the action with Fort Fisher and the Federal Point batteries, 13 to 15 January 1865.
Error: 1864 Mar 5 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.

Served on board the U.S.S. Marmora off Yazoo City, Miss., 5 March 1864. Embarking from the Marmora with a 12-pound howitzer mounted on a field carriage, Franks landed with the gun and crew in the midst of heated battle and, bravely standing by his gun despite enemy rifle fire which cut the gun carriage and rammer contributed to the turning back of the enemy during the fierce engagement.
Error: 1863 May 22 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Gallantry in the charge of the "volunteer storming party."
Error: 1863 May 22 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Error: 1864 May 12 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Error: 1862 Dec 31 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Voluntarily went to the front and picked up and carried to a place of safety, under a heavy fire from the enemy, an acting field officer who had been wounded, and was about to fall into enemy hands.
Error: 1864 August 5 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
As pilot of the flagship, U.S.S. Hartford, during action against Fort Morgan, rebel gunboats and the ram Tennessee, in Mobile Bay, 5 August 1864.
Error: 1865 Jan 15 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Volunteered to carry the brigade flag after the bearer was wounded.
Error: 1862 May 31 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Continued fighting, although wounded, until he fainted from loss of blood.
Error: 1863 May 22 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Gallantry in the charge of the "volunteer storming party."

Error: 1862 December 13 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input. and Error: 1863 May 3 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
At Fredericksburg seized the colors and led the command through a terrible fire of cannon and musketry. In a hand-to-hand fight at Chancellorsville, recaptured the colors of his regiment.
Error: 1862 April 24 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Served on board the U.S. Steam Gunboat Pinola during action against Forts Jackson and St. Philip, and during the taking of New Orleans, 24 April 1862.
Error: 1863 May 22 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.

Error: 1865 January 13 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input. – Error: 1865 January 15 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
On board the U.S.S. Ticonderoga during attacks on Fort Fisher, 13 to 15 January 1865.
Error: 1863 Jul 3 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.

All the officers of his battery having been killed or wounded and five of its guns disabled in Pickett's assault, he succeeded to the command and fought the remaining gun with most distinguished gallantry until the battery was ordered withdrawn.
Error: 1865 Apr 9 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Error: 1863 Jul 2 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Was 1 of 6 volunteers who charged upon a log house near Devil's Den, where a squad of the enemy's sharpshooters were sheltered, and compelled their surrender.
Error: 1864 Jun 12 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.

Voluntarily carrier a box of ammunition across an open space swept by the enemy's fire to the relief of an outpost whose ammunition had become almost exhausted, but which was thus enabled to hold its important position.
